newsitem.title: USA: OPTIONS- T-bond vols bounce, expiry trigger uptick.
newsitem.headline: OPTIONS- T-bond vols bounce, expiry trigger uptick.

text.p: Implied volatilities for U.S. Treasury bond options bounced off early lows in late trade as the underlying bond market became choppier in the afternoon, traders said.

July T-bond futures options on the Chicago Board of Trade (CBOT) expired at noon, triggering a wave of futures buying by those who had shorted 112 calls because September futures were hovering well above 112-00 around that time, they added.
"I think there was some final covering from shorts in July 112 calls," said a trader for a brokerage firm at the CBOT.
Traders said shorting expiring options had been a popular play in recent months as futures tended to stick around the strike price with high open interest concentration.

September T-bond futures were hovering near 112-1/2 for most of the morning, after closing at 112-6/32 on Thursday, and then rallied to a high of 112-24/32 in the afternoon following the July option expiration.
July 112 calls had open interest of 31,608 contracts at the end of Thursday's session, while 111 and 113 calls had 18,757 and 15,247 respectively.
Open interest in July 112 puts stood at 12,987 contracts as of Thursday, while that in 111 and 113 puts stood at 13,640 and 143 respectively.
A trader for a bank affiliate said that there was good interest in bonds from fund managers to start with, and that probably resulted in the July call short-squeeze.

"There seemed to be a lot of fund activity going on that pretty much washed out the big open interest in the 112 calls," he said. "I think the funds overwhelmed the market with buy orders (in bonds) today."
On the whole, option flows were moderate.
Volatilities eased in early trade as market-makers marked down weekend time-decay, and then bounced back up due in part to the rally in bonds despite overbought technical indicators.
Implied volatilities for August and September T-bond futures options were assessed at around 7.5 and 8.2 percent in late trade, virtually unchanged on the day.
At the shorter end of the yield curve, Eurodollar options on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME) had a slow day as the underlying futures market edged marginally firmer.
"Bonds are rallying big and the Euros can't rally at all -- we're only up one tick (basis point in December futures)," said a trader for a European firm.
Implied volatility for December Eurodollar futures options was off 0.2 point at 9.8 percent shortly before the close.
Among the largest trades, a Japanese firm was said to have sold some 2,500 contracts of December 93.75/94.20 strangles.
